messages: f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (16:19): Anyone care to comment? http://static.webvm.net/audio/test.html
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (16:34): f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678: don't nest <audio>
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (16:34): f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678: use <audio><source>
002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570 (16:34): http://www.w3.org/2001/tag/2009/10/08-minutes.html#item07
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:35): 002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570: I don't follow. Is LMM arguing against the TAG MIME Respect finding or for it?
002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570 (16:35): I'm not sure I entirely follow either.
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (16:39): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: ok, updated... though i am not sure about codecs for mp3/wav
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:44): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: At the least I get the sense that someone is arguing against making the HTML/XHTML distinction a property of the MIME type
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:45): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: that ship sailed years ago
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:45): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: not everyone on the TAG has a clear view of the harbor
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:46): I'm not suggesting it is a sane thing to be arguning :)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:46): er, meant that comment for b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 but you guys know what I meant

f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (16:51): I am little confused by audio loop http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#attr-media-loop When combined with autoplay... should it just play continuously?

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:52): I don't think anyone suggested switching browser *behavior* for XHTML/HTML based on anything other than MIME type, but there was an argument that it's ok if some document that in some sense "is" XHTML as text/html, if processing as HTML is what you want
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:52): I think, anyway
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:52): minutes are muddled
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:55): doesn't really understand the distinction between what a document is and how it behaves
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:56): But that is some sort of philosophical position I guess

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:58): well, the spec introduces this distinction somewhat, when it says, "XML documents that use elements or attributes from the HTML namespace and that are served over the wire (e.g. by HTTP) must be sent using an XML MIME type such as application/xml or application/xhtml+xml and must not be served as text/html."
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:58): so that raises the question whether a document "is" an XML document - particularly tricky in light of polyglot document support
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:59): the spec already says separately that anything sent as text/html will be treated as HTML
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (16:59): fwiw, I think the above paragraph is not necessary, or at least should be worded differently
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:00): I'm not sure I even know what that paragraph means
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (17:00): it should just say that documents in the HTML namespace served with an XML mime type must conform to the XML (XHTML) syntax
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (17:00): and that documents served as text/html must conform to the HTML syntax
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (17:00): and leave it at that
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:01): I think the MIME type registrations included in the document might already say that
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:01): (maybe not as to XML documents served as text/xml or application/xml instead of application/xhtml+xml)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:02): but yeah, anything that doesn't form to the HTML syntax must not be served as text/html

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:02): anything that conforms to the XML syntax either is also valid HTML (in which case you can in fact send it as text/html), or it's not, in which case it's already invalid
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (17:02): "Definition: A data object is an XML document if it is well-formed, as defined in this specification." - What is a data object?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:03): the sentence I cited superficially seems to forbid serving polyglot documents as text/html, which is inconsistent with the rest of the spec
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (17:04): yeah
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (17:05): I don't think it's necessary for it to have that prohibition nor anything similar
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:06): I don't think it even means to prohibit that

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:07): it seems like it assumes there's some platonic sense in which something is either an HTML document or an XML document (based on author's intent? I dunno) and thus can't really be checked
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (17:07): yeah, that's a good way to put it
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:08): it sort of seems like it's saying "don't serve XHTML as HTML unless you know it's not really going to get processed as XML"
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (17:14): "Don't serve XHTML as text/html unless it's also valid HTML"
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:14): that would be a fine thing to say
